comment.author: 8087163@N05
comment._content:
More likely to be a train timetable so he knows what trains to expect on the line I'd think!  Great shot of a era now lost - thanks for posting this Carol, brings back many memories of being a student in NIHE (now University of Limerick) and travelling back on a Sunday afternoon from Thurles to Limerick's Colbert station via Limerick Junction...
Would you have a photograph in the collection of Mr O'Hora the Station Master in Limerick Junction in the last 1970's?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pmcdonnell] We have a Mr O'Hagan, who's descibed as Supt. of Limerick? But out of 89 O'Dea photos taken at Limerick Junction over the years, no mention of Mr O'Hora. (Though did find one of the gloriously named Goldie Flaherty - we might have to have a look at him one of the days.)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 68262918@N00
comment._content:
Book looks too floppy to be a rule book, too small to be a working timetable and too many pages to be the weekly circular, looks like a paperback novel to me.
I don't recall very many railwaymen reading bibles, at least down south. The newspaper was the reading material of choice.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/68262918@N00] Another vote for paperback novel then!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
